replies.body: Skyrim is an overpriced unfinished Early Access game that just has an overly passionate modding scene for it for some reason.

> [{quoted}](name=SEKAI,realm=OCE,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=LNegJEoH,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2019-08-18T19:48:56.557+0000)
>
> Skyrim is an overpriced unfinished Early Access game that just has an overly passionate modding scene for it for some reason.

Skyrim is amazing you literally have no idea what you're talking about

> [{quoted}](name=CaptainAntiHeroz,realm=NA,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=LNegJEoH,comment-id=00010000,timestamp=2019-08-18T19:50:38.388+0000)
>
> Skyrim is amazing you literally have no idea what you're talking about

Unless the DLCs changed it, I played the base game and hated it to my guts. Never have I played a RPG where I was actively punished for specialising my character's build in a leveling system that force you to be the master of everything or else you can't even level; never had I played a RPG where your body armour and your leg armour are the same piece that's also attached to a shockingly barren armour and weapon option diversity (ie there is no diversity at all since especially the armour is completely linear progression) it's genuinely concern whether Bethesda even knows what an action game even is; never have I played a singleplayer RPG with quests so mindblowingly dull where especially the main quest lasted only as long as half a sleep session and also made no sense while they were at it, while the side quests were certainly a lot better it wasn't that much better barring a very few selection of side question you could feel the devs actually tried and cared; never have I played a game so devoid of ANY quality control that they couldn't even get the OPENING CUTSCENE right where I was locked out of starting my very first playthrough until 2 relaunches later because Alduin wouldn't get onto that fucking tower to start my damn game, you'd think they would at least get the scripted event that's the VERY FIRST THING you see in the game working 100% but apparently not (this is to say, bugs were everywhere, including that time there were 2 critical bugs in the already laughably short main quest that you couldn't actually progress past without cheating with console commands); never have I walked through a game world so vast and yet so empty and soul-less, where "do whatever you want" may be the slogan but there is little to nothing to actually do (I also got sick of the copy paste dungeons where only the Dwemer ruins actually have any sort of originality in them); and never have I played a game where they not just screwed up random encounter so bad but they dragged DRAGONS down with it and made them absolutely appalling instead of making me excited like I SHOULD BE when I hear about dragons; and never have I played a game with swords and magic where both combat options are as dull and derivative as they are in Skyrim, I guess we could forgive the swords and arrows but certainly not magic, like how do you even make magic as boring as it is in Skyrim's base game (and the invisibility spell literally doesn't work and is somehow flat out inferior to stealth squatting that for some reason instantly makes you disappear from reality even if you squat right in front of someone in broad day light so long you pass the stat-check); etc etc.

Skyrim is a clearly unfinished mess. Full of questionable design decisions that wouldn't even stand on its own even if they were to be put in a more polished and competent game, but ofc, they have to exist in a game like Skyrim where it's half-stuck in Alpha that expects the players to do the developers job of actually making the damn game; while they charge the players who actually made the game the full price for their efforts, I guess.
Ya. Not sure what you are describing. That's not Skyrim. Skyrim is wonderful and I don't even play it religiously.

> [{quoted}](name=WhyEvenBotherFR,realm=NA,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=LNegJEoH,comment-id=0001000000000001,timestamp=2019-08-18T20:49:18.054+0000)
>
> Ya. Not sure what you are describing. That's not Skyrim. Skyrim is wonderful and I don't even play it religiously.

That is Skyrim's base game.

Try playing it without mods. It's a garbage dumpster fire of empty nothingness and the few things that actually exist are either barebones or strung in the wrong order/design.

And you have to watch out for an obscene level of bugs. I formed a habit of making a new save every 5 minute when I played Skyrim and had to take a while to finally got rid of that fucking habit given to me by a broken game.
Or actually spend $60 for the whole game with the DLCs without mods. It's what I do. You sound salty lol
You don't even have to pay that much these days. Just catch it on sale.

Strange. I always play games without mods on first try, and i haven't noticed any game-breaking bug in Skyrim. I got a random freeze in like every 6 hours, if i played that much without closing the game.

I do admit, that it's overhyped, but remember who gave us the *POWER* to mod it. Who created, and gave the first mod tool freely, who designed the engine that let us change *EVERYTHING*. The reason of it's popularity is, because you can mod it so deeply. Can you do the same to a Mass Effect? Can you alter the animations, the weapon, and armor stats, introduce new items, change every single dialogue on every single quest, add new followers, or even create your very own DLC?

Skyrim's power is the fact, that you can make it "perfect". It doesn't matter what kind of fantasy RPG game you are looking for. Be it dark souls like super hard combat, or massive number of choices, plots behind plots, a shiny graphical image, or even a sex-slave simulator. Mods on PC can make it happen.

You probably played it a lot later than I did.

The game is probably reasonably patched out now, after almost a decade of community fixing that is which they just stole to be incorporated into the base game (and funny story, most of it is taken from Unofficial Skyrim Patch that was released almost as soon as the game was out, fixing THOUSANDS of bugs, updates every time Skytim gets a patch, and was all the work of like 1 or 2 guys; no prizes for guessing why Bethesda couldn't match that, especially since Fallout 76 bullshit).

When I played, there wasn't even any expansion pack out yet so it was pretty early. And the game was buggy as sin. if anyone had developed a habit of over-saving the game between the year 2011 to 2017 and you asked them where and how they developed this habit, I can guarantee you 8 out of 10 would tell you something along the lines of "well, I played Skyrim".

Also, the modding tool is just the development kit. The devs at Bethesda were just too lazy to actually use it to develop the actual game so they release the actual development kit hoping players would forgive them for not actually doing their job of making the game, but somehow the fans just ate it up.

This isn't to say modding is a bad thing. But Skyrim wouldn't be the first and only game to release the development kit for the players to mod at their leisure; I mean, where do you think League even came about if not for the fact it was from DotA which was a custom map made on the Warcraft3 game using Blizzard's Map Editor (and yes, you can change just about most things about the game with it and a good use of other design techniques)? The catch is that other games usually are released far more complete than Skyrim when it comes to the base game so I guess people just defend that more because that's just about the biggest thing that's defensible about Skyrim, but hey.

I've said this before and I've said it again. Mods should exist to make great games even better, it shouldn't exist to make trash games good; the players shouldn't pay the devs to do the job of actually making the base game for them, that's insane.

crafting, followers, impactful choices

> [{quoted}](name=CaptainAntiHeroz,realm=NA,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=LNegJEoH,comment-id=0001000000000000,timestamp=2019-08-18T20:24:29.716+0000)
>
> clearly didn't play it enough to learn how it works because it gives you multiple alternatives to solving most problems

You would only say that if you only played the start of the game. Since the missions that showed up at the start of the game tend to be the only ones that have multiple solutions; and by that I mean actual multiple outcomes.

Deciding to not do a quest and leave it hanging or failing it on purpose is not alternative solution to the quest. Because that's 95% the only choice you have regarding your quests, which is to say you have none; you can't even decline in getting a quest since they will force it onto you, and your only choice is to run away from them as fast as possible hoping they don't catch up to force you into a dialogue of which that dumps you the quest. It is both hilarious and sad.

The quest variety aren't something to write home about too. 90% of the quest are textbook fetch quests. Quests in singleplayer RPGs are more imaginative than this.

> crafting, 

Skyrim's system of crafting is about as streamlined as the crafting system present in MMORPGs. In fact, it's actually simpler you actually need a larger variety of materials to craft shit even in MMOs. And the alchemy and enchanting aspect in the base game could only be described as primitive and barebones; alchemy is alright and solid but it's bad because the game's combat and difficulty is so badly designed and balanced so potions can only ever either be something you outright never touch or something you spend the vast majority of every fight dumping down your throat; enchantment is just the most generic form there ever is and it's also totally useless since you need to constantly refill it ever every couple swings.

> followers, 

They are just glorified dogs. Not even kidding, they use the same in-game logic as the dog companion you could get.

They just can carry shit for you. There's nothing noteworthy about followers barring that they are a nuisance that ruin stealth, set off all the traps in the dungeon, block fucking doorways all the time, and occasionally useful such as the fact you get give them a single arrow and they'd have infinite arrows (and ranged followers is basically the only way a follower is any remotely useful since they also wouldn't be blocking the doors as much as if they were melee).

> impactful choices

There's second to none. Let's not kid ourselves.

An impactful choice would be something like in this indie Metroidvania game called Valdis Story where ignoring certain bosses and not eliminating them within a certain time frame makes the boss invade and wipe off a whole settlement of citizen; or say, in Morrowind where you have to actually make decisions since everything have varying relationships with each other, and you can't just be the master of every technique and ability imaginable, the guild master of every guild, and the thane of every hold, the champion of all the daedra featured in Skyrim, all at the same time like you could and is encouraged to be in Skyrim.

> and the community has just been making it better and better

Modding should be making a good game better, not making rubbish playable or somehow the players should be the one to design the damn game since that's the dev's job.

Played through it multiple times and you clearly have no idea what you're talking about
sure the crafting isn't as in depth as say fallout or some mmos
But literally the Civil war itself is a huge decision that will impact a multitude of people and places on its own
Same with the companions and the events that happen in Dawnguard 
And sure the companions are lacking at some times but modders have been steadily working on overhauling aspects like stagnant companions, enhancing enchanting, magic, crafting, perks
And even without those the game itself is more than competent on its own

> [{quoted}](name=CaptainAntiHeroz,realm=NA,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=LNegJEoH,comment-id=000100000000000000000000,timestamp=2019-08-18T23:38:39.057+0000)
>
> Played through it multiple times and you clearly have no idea what you're talking about
> sure the crafting isn't as in depth as say fallout or some mmos

I assume you have to mean Fallout3, you know, the worst Fallout game next to Fallout4 and only better than Fallout 76, all of which are designed by Bethesda while the rest of the good Fallout game, such as the Fallout: New Vegas, wasn't, and the latter had a far better everything than Bethesda could ever manage to shit out of its anus.

Fun fact, Bethesda as the publisher only gave Obsidian a whopping 8 months to whip out Fallout: New Vegas from scratch, and they still made better games than Bethesda could with unlimited home budget and time allowance on say Fallout3 and Fallout4. Imagine that.

By "some MMOs", you have to refer to the pedestrian ones? Because I'm sure even WoW's crafting system is more intuitive and more comprehensive than Skyrim's, where AT THE VERY LEAST, you don't become a master blacksmith by smithing out 2000 iron daggers which Skyrim's crafting system somehow allows. And remember, singleplayer games are SUPPOSED to have better crafting system than MMOs PERIOD, if ofc, they decide to include it in as a part of the feature. The fact you even stoop as low to compare Skyrim's crafting system with "some MMOs" is the kind of apologetic low you have to go just to justify an unfinished, buggy, and badly designed base game that's Skyrim.

> But literally the Civil war itself is a huge decision that will impact a multitude of people and places on its own

It doesn't. All it changes is the outfit the generic soldiers wear at the cities (not even at the camps). And there is barely any change or progression after the civil war.

Going back to the previous example being brought up, Fallout. An actual impact of multitude would be something like in Fallout: New Vagas, a Fallout game Bethesda didn't make, where failing to disarm a bomb on the monorail meant the bomb goes off and disables the monorail permanently on that playthrough. Nothing of the sort happens in Skyrim, all consequences are tuned intentionally by the devs to keep to the absolute minimal and result in things as big as a regime change being merely an outfit change for the NPCs and quite literally nothing else.

Is there new laws that are enacted that forbade the usage of the term "By the Nine!" if the Imperials were to win the war, given the Imperials do not acknowledge/recognise Talos? The answer is obviously no, even when it is as simple as adding a single 'if statement' to the game code that excludes the usage of the line from the quote rotation (no need for re-recording lines, all it needs is that those that do use the line is forced by law not to use it and so they were forced to shut up about their faith).

Regime change also doesn't result in characters in position of power resigning due to ideological disagreement or executed due to previous affiliation reasons. Yeah sure, Solitude and Windhelm's leadership change as their leaders are both the faction's leaders so either of them die at the end of the war, but other than that, nothing really change even in Windhelm and in Solitude and the only differences are mostly superficial level; and outside of that, there is literally no change in any other hold, people of other settlements don't seem to even care about the regime change. They could've done anything to make the civil war more impactful, but they kept it at the absolute minimum either because of some misguided design logic, laziness, or a bit of both.

The same goes for the fact nothing you do is acknowledged in the game whatsoever barring an extreme handful of instances. You can kill a dragon in Whiterun, literally in the city as the citizens cower and the dragon flexing its flamethrower on the houses while perching on the palace and the heroic you showed up and defeat the dragon saving the day, and the assholes who've always been anal to you would still be an asshole regardless how many lives and their fat-ass you've saved them that day; or the guards would still treat you like a peasant even if you belt all over your body the literal dragon bones while brandishing a glowing majestic magical sword or if you are the literal thane of the very hold the guard is serving.

As far as the game is concerned, hardly any choice actually matters since almost nothing will actually change regardless of the size of the event and the decision. The lack of your impact to the game world as well as the absolute absence of any urgency or consequences/choice is indeed, one of the major criticism of the game that's even well covered by mainstream game reviewers. 

> Same with the companions and the events that happen in Dawnguard 

Companions are nothing to write homes for since as far as the game is concerned they are just companion dogs that use voice lines and can carry stuff for you. And they don't do anything different from that.

I also made it clear I only focused on the base game. Obviously expansions add to the game and they are kept at a higher quality than the base since the scale is smaller. That's common sense. Or are you so desperate to praise Skyrim the fact the DLC isn't as rubbish as the base game means it's worthy of praise?

Tons of shit games have good expansion/DLC, even Diablo3 has it after the shitshow that was the game's initial launch. It's not a high bar to clear and you shouldn't treat it as one.

> And sure the companions are lacking at some times but modders have been steadily working on overhauling aspects like stagnant companions, enhancing enchanting, magic, crafting, perks

The modders shouldn't have done the developer's job.

Nothing changes the fact the things in the base game were hilariously unfinished, sometimes not even started, and the obsessive playerbase making the game on the behalf of the game dev doesn't change a single fact the base game was a piece of shit.

Modding should be making a great game even better, and not making a shit game good.

> And even without those the game itself is more than competent on its own

It isn't.

Say what you want about Oblivion, but at least Bethesda seemed they at least still grasped game development up until Oblivion before they took the forget-pill. Barring the hilarious speech system and the fucking Oblivion gates and a couple minor things like the somewhat aggressive weapon degradation system, now that's a good game that on its own stand with its two legs that only needed a slight nudge of the modders to make the game super great. 

That is NOT the case with Skyrim. The base game was barren where the game world, the scenery, is almost as far as the devs ever got to do the game and the rest were barely started besides a few interest locations that you knew that actually went through development such as things like the Dwemer ruines and for some reason Markarth (which had a crazy amount of the game's best contents in it, despite being stationed at the map's corner and treated seemingly without much care as no quest barring like 1 in the end of the main quest actively made you visit that region unlike the other ones. Markarth is the most memorable hold that gets the least attention from the game itself), while the rest were obviously just cobbled together copy pasta contents like dungeons that probably each received about 3-4 hours in a map kit, the  yet another bandit hideouts (hilariously, the vast majority of Skyrim's population are either bandits or undeads; the former is reinforced by the fact normal citizens only ever exist in settlements and none of which exist or move outside of it, so we get 99.5% of the map space being occupied by hostile entities like a post-apocalyptic wasteland except Skyrim is supposed to be a land with civilisation and order. There is a reason why the Imperial City occupied such a large area on the map of Oblivion and most part of the overworld, excluding dungeons, is basically non-hostile because that's what actually makes sense). and broken RNG then dominates a good chunk of the things that would happen in the game due to the obscene amount of encounters being decided by them. 

For fuck's sake, Whiterun, the hold that they clearly spent the most time working on next to Solitude, wasn't even finished and you see shit like that snobby self-proclaimed rich guy ended up living in someone else's home.

Skyrim's base game did NOT stand on its own, it's quite literally in alpha if we strip away the graphical assets. Let's all be real.

Maybe it was too ambitious and larger than Bethesda could've chewed back in 2011. Maybe. But it doesn't change the fact the base game was VERY unfinished. You could like it in spite of it, sure, but you couldn't just deny that fact.

The game has a huge number of choices by default on how you approach stuff. There are only 2 true weakness.

1. The combat system is rather primitive.
2. Most quest are do it, or do not do it. There are no multiple paths, or methods.

The "all skill must leveled". Well. I think you failed to fully understand how Skyrim actually works. And partly failed to see it's wonder.

Unlike "traditional" RPGs. Skyrim gives no EXP for quests. You get XP for using your skills, and the game does not expect you to do EVERY QUEST. In fact it's great for roleplay. You aren't bound to do every quest, get involved in every dirty work, and do all the stuff so you can be super powerful, and have easier times defeating the main boss. Instead you do whatever you want. Choose your path, and ignore the rest. And believe it or not "XP." will not make you more powerful.

Because the second part is, that unlike "traditional" RPGs. Nearly 99% of the enemies are leveled up to a certain level. Meaning that, if you set yourself to lvl50 at start with all the skills, but no gear behind it, then. YOU ARE GONA HAVE A BAD TIME. You are the most powerful if you only level a small number of skills, and get proper gear to back them up.

One example is only leveling two-handed, Restoration, Smithing, Heavy-armor, Enchanting. You level all of these to 100, get your armor capped with all the damage enchantement, and you gona be a freaking god. You level up illusion "just cause", and you get a bunch of levels increasing your enemies level, but barely increasing your own power.

If you specialise yourself to just 3 skill trees, which I did with one of my first characters which I only leveled 2-hand, heavy armour, and smithing. That character couldn't make past level 28 so long I don't go out of my way to do other things if I recall correctly. I eventually plateaued at level 30s after accidentally catching xp from doing other things and it was at that level that character beat Alduin. Granted, I didn't play on a hard difficulty due to the primitive combat system mentioned that I felt was nothing but a chore, especially if you're a melee character where on a higher difficulty you're just playing inventory sim and spamming potions, so why bother; so you can imagine how thrilled I was with the experience with being denied the fun both ways.

Enemies in Skyrim are not only scaled, but also higher end enemies and items also spawn with respect to your level, so long we're not talking about a guaranteed drop like a specific quest reward like Dawnbreaker (which they have a tendency to, or at least used to, if I recall correctly, scale their base damage with your level so you're also punished with a shittier version of the weapon by attempting the quest at a lower level because reasons). It's not as extreme as it was in Oblivion where combat is basically equally hard regardless of how geared and how leveled you are since all mob's combat stats scale with your own, but in trying to fix that Bethesda simply turned it into another pit of problems by changing the stat scaling problem into a spawn scaling problem. The actual problem remains almost unchanged.

There's really not a lot of RNG in Skyrim. Sure, some spawns are semi-randomized, but for the most part, there are spots where bandits spawn, spots where dragons spawn, spots where wolves spawn, etc. I have never been in the situation you described, not in my hundreds (nearing thousands) of hours playing both vanilla and modded, console and PC. I have played magic characters, sword and board characters and many many stealth characters, and my biggest criticism of the systems is that magic can feel weak or worse boring at times, especially when compared to previous Elder Scrolls games. 

I don't think I've ever had to deal with 2-3 dragons, so I know you're not talking about vanilla Skyrim. Dragons spawn pretty rarely compared to other enemies, they only spawn one at a time, and they also are enemy agnostic: they kill pretty much anything, even bandits and wolves that want to kill you. And guess what? Dragons don't even spawn if you don't progress to a certain point in the main story. So if you want to play a stealthy hunter who worships Hircine or whatever (which I've actually done recently) you can just tell the main quest to fuck off and do that, and dragons will never spawn. On top of that, if you DO progress through the main quest, Dragons become a joke with the right abilities and enough level progression. The only time I've ever had trouble with Dragons past a certain point is with mods that increase difficulty. Also, who gives a crap if a courier dies? 

I prefer the systems of previous Elder Scroll games, to be honest. I think the problem isn't that Skyrim wants you to be too generalist, its that even if you start specialist, you will inevitably become generalist if you play long enough. Unless you RP like I do and have characters that don't use certain skills at all, the way the game is designed doesn't FORCE you to switch to, say, bows after you've mastered melee. But there's nothing STOPPING you from doing it, so most casual players just eventually master everything. You can also go through every quest line despite being a specialist; College of Winterhold you don't have to cast a single spell, you don't have to be stealthy at all for the Dark Brotherhood, etc. In previous games, you'd actually have to be somewhat skilled in magic to do the Mage Guild, for example. Play style doesn't matter because the game and the characters don't care about your play style, not because the game REQUIRES you to be generalist. It just doesn't care if you are, so casual players are more than likely going to become generalist if they play a single character long enough.
